The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain, there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soybeans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice Farming

loans.name: Khaqani

texts.en: O. Khaqani is an internally displaced person (IDP) from Nagorno-Karabakh. He is 28 and has 1 child. His small business consists of two sheep, a cow and a calf. He is hoping to broaden his business and open a small farm. He has borrowed 1200 USD from Aqroinvest CU to buy 1 cow and 1 calf.

loans.use: Going to purchase one cow and on calf

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Mr. Phan S. is 28 years old and lives with his wife in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. He is self-employed as a motor-taxi driver and earns up to $10 a day, while his wife makes around $2 a day working at a factory. This loan will be used to purchase another motorcycle for Mr. S. to operate his business.

loans.use: Needs a motorcycle to operate a motor-taxi.

loans.name: Kisa

texts.en: Kisa is a thirty-two year old lady, married, with three kids. She works very hard to support her extended family that is why she runs her fast foods stall business and sells to her village and the local school. She gets very tired some days but still needs to work hard with no rest. Her first loan of $400 will be used to buy food and ingredients for the business. She says that her burden is becoming lighter, and that she is proud to be able to support her school kids. She is thinking of opening another business to help out, and a barbeque is her first choice. She believes that the more you work the more you get. Her next loan will help to pay her kids school fees and keep her current business running.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and supplies for her food stall

loans.name: Yolanda Felícita

texts.es:
Yolanda is a hardworking mother who works herself selling construction materials and steel in her small hardware store for twenty years, with the passing of time she has improved and stocked her store with a greater variety, quality and quantity of products. Now she sees the fruit of her labor when she observes the inmense work ethic of her three children. In spite of the economic problems that arose and failures in previous years with this project she never lost the will to push forward and to continue improving the well-being of her family with the help of her beloved husband. Today they have a new set of goals that they wish to accomplish and they are on the right path to achieving these goals. On a day-to-day basis Yolanda works in the hardware store, her husband works selling aggregates, and her children in their free time to help out in the family business. One of Yolanda's dreams is to convert part of the land she owns into a place where people can hold receptions and parties and in the meantime, she will continue in her hardware store improving the supply of her products and improving the infrastructure of her store. For this purpose she needs a loan. Yolanda and her family appreciate your valuable support.

Yolanda, es una trabajadora y esforzada madre D. familia que hace durante veinte años se dedica a la venta D. materiales D. construcción y fierros en su pequeña ferretería; con el paso del tiempo la ha ido mejorado y ha surtido con mayor variedad, calidad y cantidad su stock D. productos y hoy con satisfacción ve el fruto D. su trabajo cuando observa los inmensos deseos D. trabajo y superación D. sus tres hijos. A pesar D. los problemas económicos que surgieron y tras fracasar en años anteriores en esta labor jamás perdió los ánimos D. continuar y seguir adelante para completo bienestar D. su familia con la ayuda D. su querido esposo.Hoy planifican metas que desean alcanzar con constancia y mucho esfuerzo están en la senda segura para lograrlo.Día a día Yolanda se dedica a la atención D. la ferretería, su esposo a la venta D. agregados y sus hijos en sus tiempos libres se dedican a apoyar el negocio familiar. Uno D. los deseos D. Yolanda es habilitar parte D. su terreno para acondicionarlo como un local D. recepciones y arrendarlo; mientras tanto seguirá trabajando para mejorar los productos D. su ferretería y mejorar las instalaciones D. su local y para ello solicita un préstamo.Yolanda y su familia agradecen tu valioso aporte

loans.use:
Purchase of a greater variety of articles for construction and to furnish her store.

Compra de mayor variedad de artículos de construcción y acondicionamiento del espacio de ventas.

loans.name: Sodawomé

texts.fr:
Born in 1966, Mrs. Sodawomé A. is married and has 5 people under her care, some of whom are still in school. Her husband, a farmer, helps pay for household expenses, but Mrs A. also helps with the earnings from her small business. This enterprise is her main daily work, which is the preparation and sales of beans. Today, to increase her buying power and her turnover, she is asking for a loan of $300 in order to purchase sacks of beans, oil and "gari" ( fine grained cornmeal-like substance obtained from fermented manioc pulp), in sufficient quantities so as to satisfy demand. From her earnings, she will be better able to support the needs of her children, such as their schooling, health and nutrition.

Translated from French by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Née en 1966, Madame A. Sodawomé est mariée et compte à sa charge cinq (5) personnes dont certains encore en scolarité. Son mari, paysan contribue aux charges du ménage mais Madame A. participe elle aussi avec les revenus de son activité. La préparation et la vente du haricot reste son activité quotidienne. Aujourd’hui pour augmenter son pouvoir d’achat et son chiffre d’affaire, elle sollicite un financement de $300 pour acheter des sacs d’haricot, de l’huile et du gari en quantité suffisante afin de satisfaire les demandes. De ses revenus, elle pourra mieux subvenir aux besoins des enfants en matière de scolarité, de santé et d’alimentation.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of beans.

loans.name: Acholi E Group

texts.en:
Aisha is 36 years old and married with seven children. The husband is a business man. She has a stone quarrying business. She usually earns shs. 80,000 profits each week. Aisha believs that if she is given another chance to borrow, she can be able to employ other people for maximum output. Harriet has a charcoal selling business. Goretti sells used clothes and wants to use the loan to add to her stock. Betty works in a bar.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more land for stone quarrying

loans.name: Rukia's Kichangani B Group

texts.en:
Rukia O., age 38, is widowed with two children (age 12 and 7 years old). Rukia owns a vegetable stand that she started 1 year ago. Working from 7am-9pm daily, she earns about $55 a month from this business.

Rukia hopes to receive a loan in order to buy more vegetables that she can sell. Rukia belongs to the loan group called Kichangani B and will be sharing this loan with subgroup members Miza A., Mariam R., and Mariam A.. These women have businesses dealing in food vending and fish sales.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables

loans.name: Darling

texts.es:
Miss Darling is 25 years old and lives in Hialeah, where she has a general store and sells clothes and household appliances on demand. She started working five years ago in order to support herself. She requests a loan to buy products to sell and stock her general store with fruit, breads, sodas, etc. In spite of her youth, she has been working from an early age because she lives with her Aunt, who raised her. Aside from working, she studies and is an example to her community because of her effort and hard work.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer

La joven Darling de 25 años de edad habita en Hialeah en donde tiene una Pulpería, además vende ropa y electrodomésticos por encargo, desde hace cinco años empezó a trabajar para mantenerse sola. Solicita su crédito para comprar productos de ventas y abastecer su pulpería de frutas, repostería, gaseosa, etc, a pesar de su corta edad trabaja desde temprana edad ya que vive con su Tía que es su madre de crianza, además de trabajar estudia y es un ejemplo para su comunidad de esfuerzo y trabajo.

loans.use: Stock her general store (Abastecer de Inventario su Pulpería)

loans.name: Arshad's Group

texts.en: Arshad B. is the wife of Jalal Din and resides with her family in Lahore, a big city in Pakistan. Her other family members are two daughters and two boys. Both of her boys could not attend school due to various financial problems but she has now managed to send her daughters to school. Her husband works at a convenience store and both her boys supplies construction supplies. Sabra J. wants to buy CDs for their video centre; Shabana I. will also invest in her business; Azra M. needs to buy a new horse for their horse cart and Sadia B.’s husband deals in spare parts.

loans.use: expand construction supplies business

loans.name: Alemdar

texts.en:
Alemdar Q., 26, is a very energetic farmer. He keeps calves for breeding and sales. He started his business in 1999. Usually he purchases a calf from the local bazaar and during next 4-6 months he raises it and sells it to the local people in Bilasuvar Internally Displaced People Settlement.

Alemdar is married, has two sons, and lives with his parents. For so large family, it is not enough to purchase one or two calves and raise them for the next 4-6 months, so Alemdar has applied for a loan in the amount of US$ 1000 to purchase three calves at US$ 300 each and fodder for the remaining US$ 100.

loans.use: to purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Oymoma

texts.ru:
Oymoma A. lives in Khuroson. She is married and has five children. She has a vocational education. She is a pharmacist. Oymoma has opened a drugstore for the residents of her village. She now wants to increase the variety of medicines she offers. To do this, she must take out a loan. She will be able to pay it off in 10 months. She brings medicines in from the city of Dushanbe and sells them at a small clinic. This helps the population and brings in an income which helps to provide for her family.

Translated from Russian by Melissa, Kiva volunteer.

Абиерова Оймома проживает в районе Хуросон . Замужем и имеет пятерых детей. Имеет средне-специальное образование. По специальности фармацефт. Для населения своего кишлака Оймома открыла аптеку. Сейчас хочет увеличить ассортимент лекарств. Но для этого ей необходимо получить кредит. Погасить его она сможет в течении 10 месяцев. Привозит лекарства из города Душанбе и продает у себя в медпункте. Это помогает населению . а так же ей самой приносит доход , который помогает обеспечивать семью

loans.use: Increase product variety

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr:
Born around 1968 in Abomey Calavi in the Atlantique department in the south of BENIN, Mrs. Jeanne E. is married and has 6 children, of which the eldest, Anne-marie, is 25 years old, and the youngest, Terrence, is 12. She is a seamstress by profession, but in parallel with this she sells yams and fried sweet potatoes. The demands of her customers are increasing and her financial means are unable to meet them; she is asking for this loan of 100,000 francs to supply herself in order to increase her production and respond appropriately to the demands of her clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Née vers les années 1968 à Abomey Calavi dans le département de l'Atlantique au sud du BENIN, dame E. Jeanne est mariée et mère de 06 enfants dont l'aînée Anne-marie a 25 ans et le benjamin Terrance a 12 ans. Elle est couturière de profession, mais elle mène parallèlement à cette profession la vente d'igname et patate douce frites. La demande de sa clientèle étant croissante et les moyens financiers n'étant pas au rendez vous; elle sollicite ce prêt de 100 000 francs pour s'approvisionner afin d' augmenter sa production et de répondre convenablement aux demandes de sa clientèle.

loans.use: To buy 1 bag of wheat flour, 2 bags of yams, and 1 bag of sweet potatoes.

loans.name: Abdul Khalaq

texts.en:
Abdul Khalaq lives in district 15 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and has 4 children. He has a metal shop, a business that he started 12 years ago, and still he is working. He has two workers in his shop. He loves his business. During the war in Kabul, he just had to stop his business for 1 year and after that, he started again.

Now he wants to enlarge his shop so he needs some money as capital to invest. When he found AFSG in Kabul and he learned about this process of small loans, then he requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani with a term of 18 months to buy a new generator so that he can work hard and keep his business going.

He is happy with this process of small loans in this poor country. This loan can change a lot in the life of every worker. Abdul Khalaq says that that he has worked in this business for 12 years and still he couldn't expand his business. Now he would like to say that this loan is very useful for every hard worker. They can expand their business. He wants to thank Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy a new generator and complete his stock

loans.name: Ni Wayan Pori

texts.id: Wayan Pori adalah gambaran seorang istri sekaligus ibu rumah tangga yang sangat ulet membantu suaminya bertani serta mengembangkan usaha ternak babi sebagai pekerjaan lainnya. Ternak babi memang ditekuninya sejak lama terbukti Wayan tergabung dalam kelompok ternak Kembang Mekar dan setelah kerja sama dengan DINARI, Wayan mampu meningkatkan mutu babi peliharaanya. Pinjaman pertama digunakannya untuk membeli 4 ekor bibit babi serta pakannya. Selama 5 bulan pemeliharaan diperoleh keuntungan dari penjualan babinya sebesar Rp. 800.000,-. Ini bisa terjadi berkat ketekunan dari Wayan Pori memelihara babi serta pendampingan dari staf DINARI sendiri. Setelah melewati pinjaman pertama dengan hasil menggembirakan, Wayan Pori memutuskan untuk melanjutkan ke pinjaman kedua sebesar Rp. 1.500.000,-. Pinjaman ini berjangka waktu 6 bulan lalu dibelikannya 5 ekor bibit babi penggemukan serta pakannya. Wayan berharap hasil bagus pada pinjaman pertama akan merembet ke pinjaman kedua sehingga dengan demikian hasilnya akan meningkat karena populasi babinya bertambah. Pinjaman ini akan dilunasi pada akhir masa pinjaman. Keuntungan yang diperoleh Wayan sangat menolong keluarganya dalam memenuhi kebutuhan sehari-hari serta keperluan anak-anaknya.
texts.en:
Wayan Pori is a very diligent housewife. She helps her husband work the field and farm pigs on the side. She has been farming pigs for a long time. She is also a part of Kembang Mekar farming coop that is affiliated with DINARI. Through training from the group, Wayan was able to increase the quality of her farmed pigs. She used first loan obtained from DINARI to purchase 4 piglets and feeds. After 5 months, she sold the pis for $ 80 profit. This result was due to her own diligence and DINARI's technical assistance. Motivated by the success of her first loan cycle, she is currently seeking second loan for $175 with 6 months tenor. She plans to use the money to purchase 5 fattening pigs and feeds. Wayan is hopeful that she can earn more profit from more pigs. She will use the additional profit to help her family's daily finances and raise her kids.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purhcase pigs and feeds

loans.name: Lidia Paulette

texts.en: Lidia D. L. Crúz V. is a member of FINCA Perú's community bank, AnabelL.. She lives and works in Aacucho with her husband and two sons, aged 23 & 13. Her eldest son lives in Lima and is studying musical acoustics. Not only is Lydia an independent distributor of DeBelle cosmetics, she also prepares food for weekly and biweekly events including baptisms and weddings. She will invest her loan of 1000 soles into her business by purchasing more cosmetics to use as samples, bread, pork, corn, oil, and other foods she needs to prepare for the events she caters. She is currently saving to educate her children and to continue increasing her business. With the hard work she does in both of her businesses, her true dream is to continue moving forward and "sentir realizado," feel fulfilled, and have a sense of security instead of having to rely on her husband.

loans.use: Lidia would like to purchase more cosmetics to sell, and the ingredients she needs to prepare food for the events she caters.

loans.name: Jessica Esmeralda

texts.es:
La señora Jessica Esmeralda V. P. tiene 31 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Empresarias al Éxito  II  y vive en el Pasaje 2 de Mayo 116 Mz. F lote 23 del Asentamiento Humano Luis Alberto Sánchez del Puerto de Salaverry provincia de Trujillo departamento d La Libertad Perú.
Terminó secundaria completa y estudió Técnica en cosmetología, es una mujer emprendedora, a pesar de estar casada y tener dos hijos continua perfeccionándose y sigue estudiando.
Su negocio consiste en salir a domicilio y trabajar en lo que es tintes, ondulaciones, cortes, maquillaje, etc. También realiza el trabajo en su casa ocasionalmente.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles que devolvió en 4 cuotas compró una tijera que le costó 200 soles e implementó con tintes y oxigenta.
Con este crédito de 800 que será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará unas tenazas y plancha de cerámica.
Su sueño es seguir estudiando y continuar con otra profesión.
texts.en:
Jessica Esmeralda V. P. is 31 years old and belongs to the community bank “Successful Business Women II”. She lives on 2 de Mayo street 116 Mz. F lot 23, Humano Luis Alberto Sanchez of Puerto de Salaverry district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Peru. After she graduated from high school, she studied cosmetology. Jessica is a business woman and even though she is often tired and has children, she continues to improve herself with her studies. Her business is to go to people’s homes offering hair colors, perms, haircuts, make up, and more. She also works out of her home occasionally. With her first loan of 300 soles, which she paid back in 4 payments, she bought scissors that cost 200 soles and used them for hair colors and highlights. With this loan of 800 soles, which she will pay back in 6 payments, she will buy a curling iron and a ceramic straightener. Her dream is to continue studying and to find another trade.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase curling iron and ceramic straightener

loans.name: Meth

texts.en:
Mr. Meth M. is a farmer and lives in the Svay Prey village in Kampong Cham Province. He owns a plot of land that he uses to cultivate rice in order to earn a living. His wife, Mrs. Chen Neam, is a pig breeder. 

Since her business is going well, she wishes to expand it; thus, Mr. Meth M. has decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets and pig food for her business. He hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan. 

Mr. M. is 49 years old and the father of seven children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while two others stay at home to do housework and help the parents with chores. The remaining three are enrolled in the local school. His wife is shown with him here in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig food for his wife's business.

loans.name: Jose Benito

texts.es:
El Nombre del Señor José Benito B. M. tiene la edad de 51 años, su estado civil es casado, Don José tiene 1 hija su edad es de 29 años y labora como docente de primaria, su compañera de vida labora en una tienda llamada Brodway, sus propósitos son invertir en materia prima para obtener mas productos ya que esto es muy importante para el ya que necesita realizar la elaboración de los productos que los clientes le pidan sus deseos son que su negocio sea el mejor de todos ya que hay mucha demanda a lo  que el se dedica y sus sueños son de darle un mejor mantenimiento a su negocio ya que por lo que los clientes tendrían mayor interés en su tienda y así podría ofertar mejor su producto.


La actividad económica a la que se dedica es joyero en lo que realiza el siguiente trabajo anillos, pulsera, cadenas, chapas, la ubicación de su negocio es de la iglesia el calvario 1 cuadra y media abajo, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 2 años, sus inicios se dan a la edad de 16 años y mas tarde decide ingresar a un taller y al paso del tiempo decide instalar su mismo negocio e inicia con las siguientes herramientas una mesa, sopletes y balanza por lo que se decide instalar este negocio y obtuvo clientes por algunos amigos que le conocían y estos hicieron que Don José tuviera fama con su joyería por lo que fue algo muy difícil de lograr pero con el apoyo de su familias y amistades lo hizo realidad, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo por lo que necesita la compra del material como lo es el oro y tiene que buscar donde se lo oferten de forma mas factible para realizar cada uno de sus productos.
texts.en:
Mr. José Benito B. M. is 51-years old and married. He has a 29-year old daughter who works as an elementary school teacher and his wife works at a store called Brodway. Mr. Jose intends to invest in raw materials for his products. This is very important, as there is already high demand for his work, and he hopes to improve his business and better maintain his store to attract more customers. He works as a jeweler, making rings, bracelets, necklaces, and earrings in a workshop one and a half blocks from the Calvario church. Mr. José has owned his business for 2 years; he began working at age 16, later taking a job in a workshop and after some time deciding to set up his own business. Starting with only a table, blowtorch, scale, and a few customers acquired through friends, Mr. José built the reputation of his jewelry shop with much difficulty but with the support of his family and friends. This loan will finance working capital to buy raw materials at the best prices, such as the gold used in his fine work.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital for raw materials

loans.name: Octavio

texts.es:
El señor Octavio R. tiene poco tiempo que adquirió su vivienda por medio de su trabajo mediante un crédito del gobierno.
 Con un crédito anterior de FVP a construido la barda, pero le esta haciendo falta el vitropiso y una cocineta. Esta solicitando un préstamo para esa nueva mejora y así tener su casa en mejores condiciones ya que tiene dos niños para los cuales quiere lo mejor.
 Trabaja en una maquiladora en el aria de técnico mecánico   y su esposa la señora Evangélica Perales se dedica a la venta de perfumes, estos son los ingresos de su familia y con el cual planean pagar el crédito. Cuando se realizo la visita al domicilio de Don Octavio se encontraba en su trabajo es por eso que en la foto aparece su esposa Doña Evangélica.
texts.en:
Octavio R. recently bought his home with the help of a government loan.

Using a previous loan from FVP, he built the fence, but now he needs to tile the floor and install a kitchenette. He has applied for the loan to make these improvements and have a more comfortable house for his two children, since he wants only the best for them.

He works as a mechanic in a factory and his wife, Evangélica Perales, sells perfumes; those are the family's sources of income, with which they will repay the loan. Octavio was at work when the loan officer came to visit, so it is his wife, Evangélica, who appears in the photo.

Translated from Spanish by John Rynne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Tile the floor

loans.name: Um

texts.en:
Um S. is a 43 year old woman who resides with her husband in Bati district, Takeo province. She and her husband are local doctors and are able to make a combined income of around $17 per day. They have opened a pharmacy from their home selling various kinds of medicines. This couple has four children, all of them are students.

Mrs. Um is asking for a loan to operate another business selling firewood. This additional business will provide the family with extra income to help improve the standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase and sell wood.

loans.name: Zulaikho

texts.en:
Zulaikho is a humble mother who, with much effort, works on her land, growing apple trees and different vegetables to later sell in the markets of the closest towns or to traders from the same area. Her responsibilities as a mother have encouraged her to pursue farming activities to continue growing the best vegetables in the area. At the same time, she raises cattle with the help of her husband and children. Now Zulaikho wishes to expand her business and to buy more cattle to improve the living standards of her beloved family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great philosophers, scientists, and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase cattle to expand the business

loans.name: May

texts.en: May G., 38, is married with 5 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the Taro Plantation and Vegetables business. May sells to the school, village people and public 4 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 Tala (about 27 USD).  SPBD loans are May’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy timber and cement for renovation of her home.

loans.use: To buy timber and cement for home improvement.

loans.name: Elsa Haydee

texts.es:
La  señora Elsa Haydee V. B. tiene 37 años y pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres del Mañana y vive en Agallpampa distrito de Mache, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudio hasta segundo de secundaria y no continuó por falta de apoyo familiar.
Actualmente vive con su pareja y tiene 2 hijos.  La socia se dedica al trabajo agrícola y también a la venta de leña y ganado para carne.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles que canceló en 4 cuotas, invirtió en compra de leña.
Con este crédito de 1,000 soles que cancelará  en 6 cuotas, piensa invertir en la compra de leña o ganado para engorde.
Elsa sueña con ver profesionales a su hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Elsa Haydee V. Baza is 37 years old and is a member of the Communal Bank Mujeres del Mañana. She lives in Agallpampa, Mache district, Otuzco province, La Libertad department, Perú. She studied until the second year of secondary school but did not continue because her family did not support her. Now she lives with her partner and she has two children. She does agricultural work and also sells wood and beef catle.

She invested her first loan of 300 soles, which she paid back in 4 payments, in buying wood. With this loan of 1000 soles, which she will pay back in 6 payments, she intends to invest in buying wood or cattle to be fattened. Elsa dreams of seeing her children have professional careers.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Chong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wood or cattle to be fattened

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina A. is a 40 year old woman. She is married and the mother of four children, who are currently in school. She lives in her husband’s house in Akim Wenchi, which is in the eastern region of Ghana. Regina works very hard to support her husband in providing for her childrens' basic needs. 

She is a food vendor who sells rice and stew by the community school where she lives. She started her business about twelve years ago to take care of her entire family. Her food production is on a low scale because of inadequate funds to support her business.

She wants to use the loan to buy more meat, vegetables, and bags of rice to produce food in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to support and provide for her family, as well as finance her childrens' education. 

Regina belongs to a village bank named ‘Nkwa Nsuo,’ which literary means living waters. She is grateful for the assistance.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat, and firewood.

loans.name: Sonia Elizabeth

texts.es: Sonia Elizabeth C. vive en un pequeño cantón llamado el rio, ubicado en el departamento de Ahuachapán junto a su esposo y sus tres hijos; a pesar que Sonia cuenta con la ayuda económica de su esposo no es suficiente para los gastos básicos de la casa ya que son 3 hijos aun son menores de edad , es por ello que Sonia ha montado un negocio en un puesto muy céntrico para que las personas compren sus productos que son a precios muy accesibles entre ellos ropa interior para niñas y damas, ropa para bebé, vestidos de niñas y  otros adornos como centros de mesa. Sonia está solicitando este crédito por que quiere surtir su negocio.
texts.en:
Sonia Elizabeth C. lives in a small canton called the river, located in the department of Ahuachapán with her husband and their three children. Although Sonia has the financial support of her husband, it is not sufficient for the basic household expenses since the three children are still minors. This is why Sonia has set up a business in a very central position so that people can buy their products at very affordable prices, including underwear for girls and women, baby clothes, baby dresses for girls and other frills such as table decorations. Sonia is requesting this loan to supply her business.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Reynolds, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supply her business

texts.es: Charito tiene 40 años, es madre soltera, vive con sus 2 hijos, quienes son estudiantes, uno cursa el 1º de primaria y el otro 3º de secundaria. Desde hace 5 años se dedica a la venta de ropa y de productos de belleza por catálogo de una línea cosmética muy reconocida a nivel nacional. Ambas cosas las lleva a vender por los diferentes lugares de su localidad, de casa en casa, dejándolas al contado y al crédito. Charito trabaja sólo por las tardes, ya que por la mañana se ocupa de las labores en el hogar. Le gusta mucho su trabajo porque por medio de él conoce a mucha gente, lo que le es beneficioso pues obtiene más clientes. La mayor dificultad que se le presenta es cuando las personas incumplen con su pago, por lo demás, dice que le va bien, pues se considera una mujer decidida y luchadora, que siempre trata de cumplir lo que se propone. Este es su 2do préstamo con MFP, y lo que le gusta de su banco comunal es que entre todos son solidarios y existe mucho compañerismo, pues todos están pendientes de las necesidades de los demás y se ayudan mutuamente. Con el dinero que solicita comprará más productos de belleza y ropa para seguir activa en su negocio.
texts.en:
Charito is a 40-year-old single mother with 2 school age children—one is in first grade while the other is in his third year of secondary school. For 5 years, she has been selling clothing and beauty products by catalogue from a nationally-known line of cosmetics. She sells these products door-to-door in her locality, accepting cash and credit payments. Charito works only evenings because she takes care of the household chores in the morning. She really likes her job because it allows her to get to know many people, which is beneficial because she obtains more customers that way. Her biggest challenge is when people do not make payments, but other than that, her business is prosperous. She considers herself a determined and hard-working woman who always tries to achieve what she sets out to do. This is her 2nd loan with MFP. What she likes about her microfinance institute is that all its members are united and there is a lot of camaraderie because they all worry about each others’ needs, and they help each other out. With the loan that she is requesting, she will purchase more beauty products and clothing so that she can keep her business afloat.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Truthful Group

texts.en:
Wilhemina is a 37-year-old woman who runs a dry goods shop out of her house.  Wilhemina has been running this business for 2 years and has plans to grow her business to having a shop outside and hopefully one day being an international company.  

The loan she is requesting will help her to restock her store.  She wants to buy additional soap, candles, and sardines particularly.   

 Wilhemina was only able to complete school up to the junior level before she had to stop.  Now Wilhemina has 3 children of her own whom she is able to send to school.  Her oldest child is 17, her second oldest is 10, and her youngest is 4.  She also cares for 4 other children who are not her own.  One is her husband's child, one is her brother-in-law’s child, one is her nephew, and the other is her granddaughter.

loans.use: Sardines, soap, candles, and other items that need restocking

loans.name: Clelia

texts.es: Clelia tiene 52 años, vive con sus 2 hijas de 20 y 22 años en su casa propia. Desde hace 20 años se dedica a las tareas agrícolas, los principales productos que cultiva son la papa, el trigo, la cebada y las habas, las cuales lleva en cada cosecha a los principales mercados de su zona. Para cada época de siembra y de cosecha contrata a personas que la puedan ayudar en esta tarea y les paga a cada una según el jornal realizado. Y aunque esta tarea sea muy agotadora es la única fuente de sustento que le permite solventar todos sus gastos, en especial la educación de sus hijas. Por ello, para el futuro Clelia desea incrementar la extensión de sus terrenos para seguir sembrando en mayor cantidad. Esta es la octava vez que tiene un crédito con MFP, está muy contenta de ver que tiene una considerable trayectoria de trabajo en su banco comunal y su deseo es de seguir en su grupo aunando esfuerzos para el bienestar común. El dinero que  viene solicitando será destinado a la compra de sacos de abono y al pago por la implementación de canales de riego en sus tierras de cultivo.
texts.en:
Clelia is 52 years old and lives in her own home with her 2 daughters, ages 20 and 22. She has been farming for 20 years, growing primarily potatoes, wheat, barley and beans. She sells her harvested crops at the major markets in her area. During the planting and harvesting seasons, she hires workers to help with these tasks and each is paid according to the amount of work done. Although this line of work is very tiring, it is the only source of income she has to pay for her living expenses and her daughters’ education. For the future, Clelia wants to increase the size of her farm so that she can continue planting in greater numbers.

This will be her eighth loan with MFP. She is very happy with the work being done by her communal bank and hopes to continue to be part of a group that works for the common good. She will use her loan to purchase sacks of fertilizer and pay to have irrigation canals implemented on her farmland.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer and implement irrigation canals

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina is a member of Ushirikiano Borrowers group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 30-year-old woman,she  is married, and a mother of two children.Her children aged 7 and 3 years.

 Paulina started her own business selling charcoal 3 years ago. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 50,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Paulina`s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more charcoal for sale. 

With the  additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Paulina hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal  for sale

loans.name: Teodosia

texts.es:
Teodosia es socia del Banco Comunal Bonanza.
Teodosia es viuda, tiene 49 años y 7 hijos, Teodosia vende leña en su casa, producto que adquiere de los productores, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su hijo.
Teodosia necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de leña.
Los sueños de Teodosia son tener una tienda en su casa e implementar una zapatería para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Teodosia is a member of the Community Bank Bonanza. She is 49 years old, widow and has seven children. She sells firewood from her home. With her son’s help, she buys the firewood from the producers.

Teodosia is requesting a loan of $700 (2000 soles), which will be invested in purchasing more firewood. She dreams of having her own store at home and creating a footwear store for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Rina Paguaga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase firewood.

loans.name: Mr. Ly Chheun Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
Mr. Ly C. fishes in the lake in his village. He is 52 years old and the father of eight children: two of them are employed in a garment factory, two others are electricians, two are enrolled in the local school, and the others are too young to work or study. His wife, Mrs. Bou Sear, is a farmer who owns a 1 hectare field of land to cultivate rice.

Mr. Ly C. needs a fishery boat and has decided to request a loan to deal this problem. He is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. This village bank consists of 17 people who live in Lvea Sar Kandal village in Kandal province.

loans.use: To buy a fishery boat

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji W. is currently in the business of selling bread and is requesting a loan to open up a bakery. Keji is 40 years old and is widowed. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase motorbikes for sale.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: open up a bakery

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles O. was a security guard at one of the security firms based in Nairobi, Kenya. As he advanced into old age, he opted to retire and concentrate more on farming as a business in his rural area back in Nambale, Busia District. As nature dictates, he buys his stock of seed twice a year due to the two rainy seasons. He is married with twelve children and plans to use the loan to buy more seed and expand his farm since he already has available stock and the rains are just round the corner. He says food business is the best. There is always someone willing to buy food fresh from the farm. Charles O. requires a loan of Kshs. 10,000.

loans.use: Buy seeds and expand his farming area.

loans.name: Magenda

texts.en:
Magenda A. is from the village of Poblacion, Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old. Magenda is separated from her spouse and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Magenda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products such as canned goods, soaps, shampoos, chips, beverages, etc. in the local community. Magenda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Magenda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Magenda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Magenda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Magenda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en:
Edgar is engaged in the manufacturing of different kinds of furniture. He produces chairs, tables, cabinets, beds and a lot more. He hopes to maintain and continuously improve his business. With enough capital, he hopes to expand his business to earn more income for his family.

He is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000 as additional capital to buy the needed materials for his business. He needs more wood in order to produce more furniture. He hopes that his 3rd cycle loan request will be approved.

Edgar is 45 years old. He lives together with his family in the village of Ballacong, Ilagan, Isabela. He and his wife, Elizabeth, have four children, all of whom are currently studying. As the head of the family, he is trying to provide for their needs, especially when it comes to their educational needs. He also wants them to have a good future. That’s why he does his best to send them all to school.

loans.use: To buy materials for his furniture making business

loans.name: Eunice Tabu

texts.en:
Eunice Tabu K. is 32 years and married to Kasena Baya. Together they have six children between the ages of 2 and 16. They live in Malindi.

Eunice has been in the farming business for 12 years. She earns a monthly profit of 2,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from farming. She plans to use the loan to purchase maize seedlings, fertilizers, and pesticides in order to boost her crop output. With the extra earnings she hopes to purchase a water pump.

Eunice describes herself as hardworking and dreams of building a lovely, fully furnished family home.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To hire labor and to buy hybrid maize, petrol, pesticides, and fertilizer.

loans.name: Rashid

texts.en:
Rashid is an existing Kiva client. Now he applies for the loan of 2,000 AZN to buy fruit and vegetables to improve his business.

When he applied for his first loan, he sold only cabbages and then with this loan he improved his business and started selling fruits and vegetables.

"I am very thankful to Kiva for this business that you see in the photo!"

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is 22 years old and sells snacks such as mandazis and samosas to neighbors and passerbys. She hopes to use the loan in order to increase her stock and buy flour and oil at wholesale prices, so she can make a profit. She has been in the business for 5 years. She is married and her husband is unemployed. They have three children who are 6, 8 and 9 years old. The oldest child is adopted.

She hopes to improve her business to educate her children and pay rent. She also hopes to someday become a supplier of her products to retail outlets. She describes herself as industrious and honest.

loans.use: To increase stock.

loans.name: Ana Bertha

texts.es:
Ana es socia del Banco Comunal Alegría Huamanga.
Ana es casada, tiene 34 años y 4 hijos, Ana junto a su esposo tienen un estudio jurídico en un local alquilado, su esposo es Abogado y ella se encarga de la secretaria.
Ana necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de una computadora y hacer instalar Internet en la oficina.
Los sueños de Ana son que sus hijos tengan una buena educación y mejorar su casa.
texts.en:
Ana is a member of the Alegría Huamanga Microfinance Institute.

Ana is a 34-year-old married mother with 4 children. Ana and her husband have their own legal office in a rented space. Her husband is a lawyer and she takes care of the office work.

Ana needs a 1,500.00 PEN loan, which will be used for purchasing a new computer and connecting it to the internet.

Ana dreams of her children having a quality education and of home improvement.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a computer and internet installation

loans.name: Rodgimar

texts.en:
Rodgimar A., 25 years old, told CEVI that he is engaged in multi-business. Aside from seaweed, he also sells fish and seashells in his village.

Rodgimar was not able to go to school because of financial difficulty in his family and that is why he toils so hard in his seaweed business to be able to earn income and save money for the future.

Rodgimar would like to grow his business more. He hopes to receive a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy seaweed seedlings for his seaweed farm and fish that he resells in the market.

loans.use: To buy seaweed seedlings for his seaweed farm and more fish to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen has a farm where she plants cassava to sell to resellers. She also sells fruit and cassava dough.  She is a hard working woman and she hopes to lift her family and business above poverty. She is 35 years-old and married with eight children. Her children are still young and dependent on her. She is a Kiva partner Lift Above Poverty Organisation (LAPO) client. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more cassava stems to plant and sell. She says a big thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase cassava stems.

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife R. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 48 years old. Marife is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Marife owns and operates a specialized retail store in the local community, selling different vegetables and spices for cooking. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $130 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Marife joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in the business. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina O., 58, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Leonisio O., a retiree who is receiving pension, they are blessed with six children, five of whom are already married. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Josefina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries needed to replenish stocks and continue operation of her variety store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries needed to replenish stocks and continue operation of her variety store.

loans.name: Sam Art

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam Art Y. is 52 years old and is a villager who lives in Svay Chuor village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Sokhak Nget, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they grow crops to earn a living.

In this farming, they face a problem because the field is far from the irrigation system. Thus, Mrs. Sam Art Y. decided to ask for a loan to purchase a water pump and gasoline to pump water to support her farm crops.

Mrs. Sam Art Y. is the mother of three children who all are students in the local school and also support their parents’ farming. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump and gasoline

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores V. is from the village of Olango. She is 51 years old, married, and has 1 adult-aged child, To make a living, she plants and harvests rice for sale. Dolores has been engaged in her business for over 26 years and earns approximately $955 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Dolores joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 29,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Dolores is requesting a new loan of 33,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers. This will be her 5th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Nyantid

texts.en:
Nyantid E. sells groundnuts and simsims (sesame seeds) at the market and is requesting a loan to also stock maize and cassava flour to sell.  Nyantid is 39 years-old and is married with a husband that is a soldier. She has four children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase maize and cassava flour to sell.

loans.name: Aminata Aziz

texts.en:
Aminata owns a stall at Victoria Park located in the middle part of the city. She trades in different type of textiles, and other clothes.

Aminata is 49 years of age and has spent eighteen years in business. She is married to a retired pharmacist and has three children: two of them are in junior secondary school with one at primary level.

Aminata is looking for a loan to enable her to acquire additional stock. She intends going to Guinea, a neighboring country, to buy goods in larger quantities and affordable prices, which will enable her to make more profit. She is hoping to open a drugstore for her retired husband with proceeds from the loan.

loans.use: To buy more textiles to sell

loans.name: Paulin

texts.fr:
Cet homme de 40 ans est célibataire. Il est propriétaire d’un bar renommé appelé « LA COUR DES GRANDS ». Il y vend des bières et boissons produites par la Brasserie de Lomé. Ces boissons sont vendues par la Brasserie aux différents tenanciers de bar  dont « LA COUR DES GRANDS » qui à leur tour les servent en détail aux clients.
L’objet du crédit est l’achat de casiers de boissons pour répondre avec satisfaction à la demande des clients en forte augmentation.
Il espère avec l’évolution probable de son activité due à ce crédit, augmenter et conforter son autonomie financière.
texts.en:
Paulin G. is a 40-year old single man who owns a well-known bar called « La Cour des Grands. » He sells beer and other beverages produced by the Brasserie de Lomé, which sells wholesale to several bars, who serve them to retail clients. The purpose of this loan is to purchase cases of beverages in order to meet M. G.’s increasing demand. He hopes this will enable him to reinforce his economic independence.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beverages for resale

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean C. is from the village of Port Area, Iligan City. She is 37 years old. Jean is widowed and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Jean owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling specialty food products like chicken and pork barbecue in the local community. Jean has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Jean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jean has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Jean is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP to use for the same purpose. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Jean from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Esterlita Bautista's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Esterlita B. is 49 years of age, married and a resident of Catadman, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental.  Esterlita is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Esterlita B.’s Group.

Esterlita is married to George Rommel B. who is an office encoder. They were blessed with 2 school aged children. To help her husband, she decided to engage in rice retailing and jewelry selling business.  For 25 years, she was able to maintain this business  activity and she is earning an average net income of not less than P3,500.00 a month in which is so helpful with their family income. 

Upon hearing the good news of PAGLAUM MPC for being one of the most outstanding cooperative in Northern Mindanao and winning the COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006 she decided to join the cooperative in the year 2009. As an active member of the PDP-LP Program of PAGLAUM MPC, a micro-finance program that reached out the rural poor, she is requesting an amount of P8,000.00 as her 3rd cycle loan to be used for additional capital for her existing rice retailing and jewelry dealing business. The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions for her family, to meet their basic needs, loan repayments to PMPC, children’s education and for possible business expansions.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her rice retailing and jewelry selling business

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina S. is a married woman who lives in Bog-ot, Argao, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures; pig fattening and a general store business. Her husband, Cirilo S., who is 48 years old, works as a cook to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  Their only child is now 23 years old.

Marcelina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marcelina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 10,000 PHP,  uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 6th loan cycle, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional working capital to expand her pig fattening business and to buy more stock for her general store so that she could continue to save up for future for the betterment of her business. Marcelina S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.
http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Improve his house by remodeling the floor and to pay for some family, personal expenses

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline L. is from the town of Banga. She is 50 years old. Evangeline is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Evangeline owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over 18 years.

Evangeline joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evangeline has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the second loan taken out by Evangeline from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Faustino

texts.es:
El Sr. Faustino  tiene 38 años y vive con su hermana.
 El desde muy joven empezó a trabajar  como limpiador de parada de taxi y luego como chofer, gracias a su esfuerzo logro comprar un vehículo y trabajar en el. 
El necesita de este crédito para la compra de cubiertas, también  realizar algunos arreglos que le  falta al vehículo  y de esta manera  brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes. Faustino   anhela  comprar otro vehículo y así obtener mejor ingreso para su familia.
texts.en:
Faustino is 38 years old, and he lives with his sister. When he was very young he started working as a cleaner of a taxi stop. Then, he became a driver. Thanks to his efforts, he managed to buy a vehicle for work. He needs the loan to buy tires and to make some needed repairs on his vehicle. This way he will provide his customers with better service. Faustino is eager to buy another vehicle to get a better income for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tires and repair his vehicle

loans.name: Kibaroudouman Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kibaroudouman, ont en moyenne 31 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Marka-coungo, sous préfecture de Fana,  région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles sont toutes mariées, se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce, de chaussures, de bois de chauffe et de gâteaux.                                                                                                            
Ces femmes du groupe Kibaroudouman sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des chaussures, de la farine de blé et du bois de chauffe.                                                                                       
BATOMA D. du groupe Kibaroudouman compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des chaussures en plastique pour enfants et adultes.
Elle s’approvisionne le plus généralement à Bamako et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Marka-Coungo au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30 000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Kibaroudouman group are 31 years-old with 3 children each, and live in large traditional families in the Marka-Coungo village, municipality of Fana, in the Koulikoro region (the second largest administrative region of Mali). They are all married and met through friends and family; they sell shoes, firewood and cakes for a living. These women are on their first microfinance loan and would use it to purchase shoes, flour and firewood. Batoma D., a member of the Kibaroudouman group, aims to use her loan to purchase plastic shoes for children and adults. She sources her goods from Bamako and sells them from the Marka-Coungo market for cash and credit sales to a customer base made up of men and women. She aims to generate an average monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA which will be used to meet her family's everyday needs, and the rest will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing shoes

loans.name: Adiza

texts.en: Adiza W. is a petty businesswoman. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a commercial driver. She sells kitchen utensils like spoons and knives, and also sells provisions like drinks, milk, soap, spaghetti, tinned tomatoes, etc. Adiza will use the loan she will take to buy more of the things she sells to stock her shop and thus expand her business. She will then use the profits she gets from her business to further her children’s education and also to help her husband to pay the utility bills for the home.

loans.use: buy more of the things she sells to stock her shop

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 55-year-old married man and father of 2 children, one of whom is still attending the school. He has been running a clothing store for the past fifteen years. He sells only woman clothes. He has a good number of clients passing by his shop because he always presents new collections to attract them. With a loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., he will expand his store’s inventory for the coming winter season. He says the loan will help him to diversify his merchandise selection. In the future, he is hoping to also sell woman shoes and bags by adding a corner for this purpose in this store.

loans.use: to expand his store’s inventory

loans.name: Joyce Punyua

texts.en:
Joyce, 23 years old, practises livestock farming and also operates a retail shop in Naivasha town.  She has been doing this since 2008. She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to buy two bags of maize, three bags of beans and five boxes of cooking fat which she will sell from her retail shop.

In future, Joyce hopes to grow her retail shop to a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy 2 bags of maize, 3 bags of beans, and 5 boxes of cooking fat to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda M., from the city of Capatan, Tuguegarao City, is 58 years old, married and has three grown children. To make a living, Erlinda owns and operates a general store selling a variety of products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over seven years, she earns approximately 4200 PHP a month.

In 2005, Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from ASKI, she is requesting a new loan of 22000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be  Erlinda's eighth loan from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Dalaijargal

texts.en: Dalaijargal N. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home, in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. All three children attend school and her husband operates a transportation business using his own mini-truck to supplement his family income. Dalaijargal operates a grocery shop in the city. She started her grocery trading business in 2007 with a small shop. Since then, she has established her business into a sustainable level and she was able to obtain permission from Expertise Agency to operate a grocery shop. After several years of operation, she has gained much experience and today, her working capital exceeds 1,100,000 MNT. Her daily average sales income is between 50,000 and 100,000 MNT. In the future, she hopes to grow her business. She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to increase her working capital for her grocery shop.

loans.use: To grow her business

loans.name: Arca De Noe Group

texts.es:
el grupo arca de noe, esta integrado 3 mujeres y esta ubicado en la aldea Fray Lazaro, a continuacion se detallan las diferentes actividades que ellas realizan:

la sra. Diana Patricia S. tiene 40 años de edad, esta casada y es madre de cuatro niños. su esposo le ayuda economicamente, Diana se dedica a la venta de pescados y refrescos.
los fines de semana vende golosinas en su casa de habitacion.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de pescado y refrescos.

la señora Tedis Estela R. O. tiene 22 años de edad, esta soltera y es madre de una niña.
Tedis se dedica a la venta de venta de ropa nueva, tambien vende golosinas.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de pantalones, blusas y dos fardos de harina de maiz para hacer las golosinas.
 
doña Mayra Jacquelin R. tiene 29 años de edad, es madre de tres hijos y se dedica a la elaboracion y venta de rosquillas, pan, tamales, y pastelitos.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de de maiz, leña, cuajada, queso, manteca, azucar. 

todas son muy amigas y muy unidas y tienen muchos deseos de salir adelante.
texts.en:
The 'Arca de Noe' (Noah's Ark) group is made up of three women and is located in the village of Fray Lazaro.  Below we detail the women's different business activities:

Diana Patricia S. is 40 years old.  She is married and has four children.  Her husband helps her financially.  Diana sells fish and soft drinks.  On weekends she sells sweet treats from her home.  She will use her loan to buy fish and soft drinks.

Tedis Estela R. O. is 22 years old.  She is single and has one daughter.  Tedis sells new clothes.  She also sells sweet treats.  She will use her loan to buy pants, blouses and two packs of corn flour to make her sweet treats.

Mayra Jacquelin R. is 29 years old.  She has three children and she makes and sells 'rosquillas' (a type of doughnut), bread, tamales and 'pastelitos' (pastries made from puff pastry with a sweet or savory filling).   She will use her loan to buy corn, firewood, 'cuajada' (a compact cheese-like product), cheese, butter and sugar.

The group are very friendly and very united and they have a great desire to get ahead.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks, fish, flour, eggs, firewood, corn, clothes, oil, butter, potatoes, chicken, tomatoes, cabbage, onion, cheese, sugar and 'cuajada'

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more gallons of ‘palm wine’ for sale

loans.name: Heligena

texts.en:
Heligena C. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 38 years-old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Heligena owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing general services such as repainting cars and jeeps for local community members. Her husband is working in their vulcanizing shops. Heligena has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Heligena joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Heligena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. Heligena is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed for the maintenance of the service. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Heligena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed.

loans.name: Herbart

texts.en:
Herbart M. is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala central region of Uganda. He is married and has one child, who is not currently in school. Herbart has a medical clinic business, which he has run for two years.
To help expand his business, Herbart has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more medicine for resale. With the help of his loan from BRAC, Herbart hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for his family. In the future, he hopes to expand his medical clinic further.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine for resale

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza is a 50-year-old widow who supports her family by operating three business ventures:  fishing, fish vending and providing manicure/pedicure services.  She lives in the municipality of Medellin, Cebu. Flordeliza joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Flordeliza has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,900, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy fishing gears and equipment so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Flordeliza is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy materials which will help solve her business problems

loans.name: Ditalala Plus Group

texts.en:
Ditalala Plus is a group of eight owners of small businesses chaired by Gyslain. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva to grow their businesses.

Gyslain is 27 years old and single. He started his business of running a telephone booth in 2006 with $120 as beginning capital. He worked very hard and his business prospered. Gyslain decided to join an MFI HOPE group in 2009 in order to, some day, achieve his dream of opening a large general shop in his area. Gyslain has already received four loans from HOPE DRC and repaid them properly. He is glad to join HOPE’s group because he hopes to enhance his business. With the next loan from HOPE, Gyslain is planning to purchase 50 packages of prepaid phone cards to resell. He intends to use the profits to increase his working capital. His business brings in about 50 USD per week and is located in the southwestern area of Kinshasa.

loans.use: To purchase 50 packages of prepaid phone cards to resell

loans.name: Pal

texts.en:
Pal U., 48, is a married woman who earns a living by selling fish in a small kiosk at home. In addition, she also raises a few pigs in a pigpen behind her house for additional income to help support the whole family. Pal U.’s husband is a good cook who provides a cooking service for ceremonies and wedding parties. He can make around $1.50 in profit per day from his occupation.
